user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1Result:
```c
static enum SHA1_RESULT
SHA1Result (struct SHA1Context *context, unsigned char
            Message_Digest[SHA1HashSize])
{
  int i;

  if (! context || ! Message_Digest)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_NULL;
  }
  if (context->corrupted)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  if (! context->computed)
  {
    SHA1PadMessage (context);
    for (i = 0; i < 64; ++i)
    {
      context->message_block[i] = 0;
    }
    context->length_low = 0;
    context->length_high = 0;
    context->computed = 1;
  }
  for (i = 0; i < SHA1HashSize; ++i)
  {
    Message_Digest[i]
      = (unsigned char) (context->intermediate_hash[i >> 2]
                         >> 8 * (3 - (i & 0x03)));
  }
  return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected the four conditional/loop fragments above because they are the places where execution may or may not reach depending on the state of the inputs and the context structure; each could therefore be a candidate for unreachable (dead) code in some build/runtime scenarios and should be investigated. Other parts of the function do not present plausible unreachable-code issues: the local declaration (int i;) is required; there are no statements placed after unconditional returns within the same block (no obvious syntactic dead code); and the final return (return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;) is the natural exit if earlier returns are not taken. There are no trailing statements after unconditional returns, no duplicate identical conditional branches, and no obviously constant-false conditions in the remaining code that would indicate further unreachable fragments.
